Input.posts:
Good afternoon, Professor.\xA0 I just watched the video on the double-slit experiment and was quite fascinated! do the particle detectors cause any kind of interference that results in the disappearance of the wave pattern?
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
That's one of the theories.\xA0 But we really do NOT understand quantum mechanics.\xA0 We have the machinery to get the 'right' answers, so we can build digital cameras, and the like, but to understand what's going on fundamentally ?\xA0 That's a big question mark, one that has consumed the thoughts of physicists and philosophers for over one hundred years, now.\xA0 And counting....

Input.posts:
That means we observe the changes better only when the changing thing itself increases. More is the brightness more better we can observe the changes in brightness. Lesser is the brightness more difficult to notice the change in brightness.For this reason i think we cannot observe Milkyway easily.We are rich in all kinds of pollution. Is this rule applicable strictly for sensors ?
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
I think you have it reversed.\xA0 If something is very bright, you need MORE change to be able to see a difference.\xA0 With mechanical sensors, however, this is not necessarily the case.\xA0 It is a matter of perception, not objective measurement.
Instructor's post : I think you have it reversed.\xA0 If something is very bright, you need MORE change to be able to see a difference.\xA0 With mechanical sensors, however, this is not necessarily the case.\xA0 It is a matter of perception, not objective measurement.
Upvotes:
0

Title: Linking forum posts - analyze-1-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructorâ€™s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.posts:
Somewhere in 1960s, Friedmann's model; that the universe is uniform, regardless of where you look it from, was verified. When they received radiations, they simply could not make out where was the source. They checked for all sorts of errors in their machine and could not get any. They moved their receiver and, again, couldn't simply make out what was the source. Well, the conclusion of this was it was because the universe is uniform all around. My question is regarding the third lecture or week one, if you move your telescope to find out the X-Ray source, how would you ever be able to make out the source? So, wouldn't they had kept getting wrong sources for X-Rays?
Upvotes:
0
Could it be you are mixing cosmic background radiation, which is pretty much uniform, and X/gamma-ray sources, which are just spots? I guess in the 60s, the image prof shows would have been just 1 pixel in a X-ray image, so you would know you have (at least) 1 source in that pixel, but you would not know where in that square (1 arcsec * 1 arcsec) the source(s) is(are). \xA0
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Actually, this goes beyond the Friedmann model.\xA0 The idea of a uniform and homogeneous Universe is a basic tenet of the Cosmological Principle.\xA0 Without this we can make no progress.\xA0 But, as pointed out above, this refers to large scale structure, looked at in a statistical fashion.\xA0 Clearly, at small distances, this breaks down.\xA0 My room, where I am typing this, is definitely going to be different from yours.\xA0 But over vast distances, 100 Mpc or more, the sky appears uniform.\xA0 From here, there, and everywhere.
Instructor's post : Actually, this goes beyond the Friedmann model.\xA0 The idea of a uniform and homogeneous Universe is a basic tenet of the Cosmological Principle.\xA0 Without this we can make no progress.\xA0 But, as pointed out above, this refers to large scale structure, looked at in a statistical fashion.\xA0 Clearly, at small distances, this breaks down.\xA0 My room, where I am typing this, is definitely going to be different from yours.\xA0 But over vast distances, 100 Mpc or more, the sky appears uniform.\xA0 From here, there, and everywhere.

Title: Linking forum posts - analyze-1-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructorâ€™s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: How a big image is collected through a small lens ?
Input.posts:
While taking photograph or looking a vehicle mirror things which are far bigger than compared to lens and mirrors can collect the image and fit to the their dimensions. Moreover light spreads out.How then light spread out of a big mountain and comes and fits into lens to get an image. If light were actually spread out by the length it approaches the lens we should be able to see a small part of the mountain, but then how we are getting full image on through the lens.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Any point on any object can be considered to radiate light in all directions.\xA0 So no matter where your lens is located, some ray ought to enter it.\xA0 A different ray, of course, will enter your eye, and yet another one will enter a person who might be standing next to you.
Instructor's post : Any point on any object can be considered to radiate light in all directions.\xA0 So no matter where your lens is located, some ray ought to enter it.\xA0 A different ray, of course, will enter your eye, and yet another one will enter a person who might be standing next to you.
Upvotes:
0

Instructor's Post
Any point on any object can be considered to radiate light in all directions.\xA0 So no matter where your lens is located, some ray ought to enter it.\xA0 A different ray, of course, will enter your eye, and yet another one will enter a person who might be standing next to you.

Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: How a big image is collected through a small lens ?
Input.posts:
While taking photograph or looking a vehicle mirror things which are far bigger than compared to lens and mirrors can collect the image and fit to the their dimensions. Moreover light spreads out.How then light spread out of a big mountain and comes and fits into lens to get an image. If light were actually spread out by the length it approaches the lens we should be able to see a small part of the mountain, but then how we are getting full image on through the lens.
